title.text: Transfer learning for health-related Twitter data

abstractContent.text: Transfer learning is promising for many NLP applications, especially in tasks with limited labeled data.
This paper describes the methods developed by team TMRLeiden for the 2019 Social Media Mining for Health Applications (SMM4H) Shared Task.

entities.text: Social Media Mining for Health Applications (SMM4H) Shared Task

abstractContent.text: Our methods use state-of-the-art transfer learning methods to classify, extract and normalise adverse drug effects (ADRs) and to classify personal health mentions from health-related tweets.

entities.text: classify personal health mentions from health-related tweets

abstractContent.text: The code and fine-tuned models are publicly available.

introductionContent.text: Transfer learning is promising for NLP applications, as it enables the use of universal pre-trained language models (LMs) for domains that suffer from a shortage of annotated data or resources, such as health-related social media.
Universal LMs have recently achieved state-of-the-art results on a range of NLP tasks, such as classification and named entity recognition (NER).

For the Shared Task of the 2019 Social Media Mining for Health Applications (SMM4H) workshop team TMRLeiden focused on employing state-ofthe-art transfer learning from universal LMs to investigate its potential in this domain.

entities.text: Social Media Mining for Health Applications (SMM4H) workshop
